title: Marinig, Cabuyao
text:
Barangay Marinig (PSGC: <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20111114182827/http%3A//www.nscb.gov.ph/activestats/psgc/municipality.asp%3Fmuncode%3D043404000%26amp%3Bregcode%3D04%26amp%3Bprovcode%3D34">043404010</a>) is one of the eighteen urbanized <a href="barangays">barangays</a> comprising the progressive <a href="City">City</a> of <a href="Cabuyao%2C%20Laguna">Cabuyao</a> in the <a href="Philippine%20province">province</a> of <a href="Laguna%20province">Laguna</a>, <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>.
Barangay Marinig lies for about one and a half kilometer away from the city proper of Cabuyao and is situated at the eastern portion of the city.
According to the 2015 <a href="Census">Census</a>, it has a population of 43,315 inhabitants (up from 25,619 from 2007), making it rank as the second largest barangay in Cabuyao in terms of population (after <a href="Barangay%20Mamatid%2C%20Cabuyao%2C%20Laguna">Barangay Mamatid</a>).
The total land area of Barangay Marinig is 391.5 hectares or 3.915 square kilometers (km2). Making it the second largest barangay in the city of Cabuyao in terms of land area.
Geography.
Political Division.
It is politically subdivided into six <a href="purok">purok</a>s in two districts:
Land Area.
The total land area of Barangay Marinig is 391.5 hectares or 3.915 square kilometers (km2). Making it the second largest barangay in the city of Cabuyao in terms of land area.
Location.
It is located at the western portion of <a href="Laguna%20de%20Bay">Laguna de Bay</a> (Laguna Lake), the country's largest lake; northwest of Barangay <a href="Gulod%2C%20Cabuyao">Gulod</a>; north east of Barangay <a href="Niugan%2C%20Cabuyao">Niugan</a>; southeast of Barangays <a href="Bigaa%2C%20Cabuyao">Bigaa</a> and <a href="Butong%2C%20Cabuyao">Butong</a>; east of Barangay <a href="Sala%2C%20Cabuyao">Sala</a> in the <a href="city">city</a> of <a href="Cabuyao">Cabuyao</a>.
It lies for about one and a half kilometer away from the city proper and is situated at the eastern portion of the city.
It is one of the six "along the lake" barangays of the city of <a href="Cabuyao">Cabuyao</a>. Which is the barangays <a href="Mamatid%2C%20Cabuyao">Mamatid</a>, <a href="Baclaran%2C%20Cabuyao">Baclaran</a>, <a href="Gulod%2C%20Cabuyao">Gulod</a>, Marinig, <a href="Butong%2C%20Cabuyao">Butong</a>, and <a href="Bigaa%2C%20Cabuyao">Bigaa</a>.
Demography.
According to the 2015 Census, it has a population of 43,315 inhabitants, it grew up from 25,619 in 2007. Making it rank as the second largest barangay in <a href="Cabuyao">Cabuyao</a> in terms of population.
Etymology.
The name "Marinig", came to be when an old man, who had an impaired sense of hearing was asked by a group of <a href="conquistador">conquistador</a>, where Crispulo Aragon belonged, what the name of the name place was, he replied, "'di ko marinig". From then on, the place was called as Barrio Marinig.
History.
Spanish Era.
When the Spaniards arrived in 1571 in the town of Tabuko (the old name of Cabuyao), they first landed in the shoreline of Marinig. These Spaniards saw the potential of the place for barter, thus, they made it the center of trade or <a href="Encomienda">Encomienda</a>.
Culture.
Marinig Fiesta.
The Fiesta of Marinig is every 24th day of August in honor of the barangay's Patron Saint, <a href="Bartholomew%20the%20Apostle">Saint Bartholomew</a>, the apostle.
<a href="Sangguniang%20Barangay">Sangguniang Barangay</a> Officials (2018-present).
